misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that x.next() will capture the entire user entry for a student's name, even if the name contains spaces (e.g., 'Alice Smith').
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that Scanner.next() only reads up to the first delimiter (whitespace). In Java, a multi-word input like 'Alice Smith' would be split, with 'Alice' being stored in the first array slot and 'Smith' being consumed by the next iteration of the loop, causing the names and scores arrays to go out of synchronization.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that even if a value has been captured into a local variable for comparison (s1 = z[j]), it must be re-fetched directly from the array (tt = z[j]) to perform a swap operation.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not realize that the local variables s1 and s2 already hold the values of z[j] and z[j+1]. Consequently, the swap could be performed using the existing local variables (z[j]=s2; z[j+1]=s1;) rather than re-indexing the array and creating an additional temporary variable tt.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array of size N must be processed for exactly N full passes of an inner comparison loop to guarantee sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In a standard Bubble Sort, only N-1 passes are required to guarantee that all elements are in place. Furthermore, the inner loop can be shortened in each subsequent pass as the largest elements 'bubble' to the end. The student's model assumes a static, fixed number of iterations.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that x.next() will read a full 'name' as a single unit, assuming that names are always single tokens or that the computer understands the logical boundary of a 'name' based on the prompt.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's Scanner, next() reads input until any whitespace is encountered. If a user enters a full name (e.g., 'Alice Smith'), next() will only capture 'Alice', leaving 'Smith' in the buffer to be incorrectly captured by the next call, leading to an InputMismatchException when the program later expects an integer for a score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to ensure an array is fully sorted, the outer loop of a bubble sort must run at least n times (once for every element) to guarantee the bubbling process is complete.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In a standard bubble sort, only n-1 passes are required to sort an array of size n, as the final element's position is determined by exclusion once all other elements are placed. While running n passes is not logically incorrect, it suggests a lack of precision in the mental model of the algorithm's termination condition.
